title: Practice Challenge
description: Apply what you've learned in this interactive coding challenge.
instructions:
Create a Vehicle counter system!

1. Class 'Vehicle' with:
   - STATIC field: int TotalVehicles = 0
   - STATIC field: int MaxSpeed = 0
   - INSTANCE fields: string Model, int Speed
2. Constructor that increments TotalVehicles
3. INSTANCE method Accelerate(int amount): increases Speed, updates static MaxSpeed if beaten
4. STATIC method ShowStats(): displays TotalVehicles and MaxSpeed
5. Create 3 vehicles, accelerate them, call ShowStats

Demonstrate the difference between static (shared) and instance (individual)!

hints.text: Static: use 'static' keyword, access via ClassName. Instance: no 'static', access via objectName. Static methods can't use 'this' or instance members!
Accessing static through instance: 'p1.TotalPlayers' might work but is WRONG! Always use ClassName.StaticMember for clarity: Player.TotalPlayers.
Using instance members in static methods: Static methods can't access instance fields! 'public static void Method() { Console.WriteLine(Name); }' is ERROR if Name is instance field.
Forgetting 'static' keyword: If you want a shared member, you MUST use 'static'. 'public int TotalPlayers' without 'static' means EACH object has its own TotalPlayers (not shared)!
When to use static: Use static for shared data (counters, constants) or utility methods (Math.Sqrt). Use instance for object-specific data (each player's score).
